meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hello everyone. Hi, good afternoon. Welcome to breakout room, um, 3.3 I think we are. Um, so communication between the gut and the brain. So we have a few questions cued up. Um, what is the diversity of messages that pass back and forth between the gut microbiome and the brain? Are these unidirectional or bidirectional channels of communication? Are there ways to perturb neuronal function to watch the microbial response and how can these communication signals be monitored, hijacked or interrupted to drive desired outcomes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I haven't been um in the same room with everybody here. I presume that that's the case since I think they're trying to mix us up. So maybe we could do some really quick introductions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: So, um, my name is Judith Eisen. I'm at the University of Oregon. I'm a neuroscientist and I really think about development of the nervous system. So how uh how does the nervous system initially get wired up? I think one of the big revelations of the let previous decade is that it's not just mom's genes and and then the your genes, but there all these other organisms with genes that are associated at least with vertebrates and they uh make molecules that uh certainly have effects on the process, not just in the nervous system but other parts of the of the animal. But um and and we don't know very much about that. I think we we've learned uh much more at this point about later effects of the microbiome on the nervous system in terms of disease states and so forth, but we don't really don't know very much about the initial initial wiring and how that might set the animal up to be predisposed or not to what happens later.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I'm sure everybody's on a different place on everybody else's screen. So I'm just going to ask people to to volunteer to say something about themselves and we'll get through everybody that way.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Mei Shen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, I can volunteer to break the ice. Hi everybody. Uh I'm Mesha. Uh I am assistant professor from University of Illinois and Urbana Champagne. So I have appointment in Department of Chemistry as well as Neuroscience program and the Department of Bioengineering. So my interests are in two folds. Uh one of them is methodology development and we are interested in developing electrochemical sensing probes that can monitor the neurotransmitters at the time scale of reoccurrence, like break communication, like namely at like millisecond um time scale. And we are also interested to make this sensing probes to be pretty small, like nanometer in size. So for example, we have a published paper where we can make them to be like 15 nanometer in radius. So we can probe synaptic neurotransmission. And currently we we are interested in prove multiple groups of neurotransmitters. Uh and very often those are like involved in neurological disorders and also um look into new methodologies to monitor uh electrical as well as chemical break communication at the same time. Yeah, I'm interesting Alzheimer's disease as well. Nice to meet you all.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Robin Voigt-Zuwala
meeting_annotations.transcript: I can go. Uh my name is Robin Voigt Zuwala. I'm an associate professor at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago. Uh my primary interests are how lifestyle factors influence microbiome and how that is influencing disease. So I work with everything from um in vitro, ex vivo, rodent models and humans. Um primarily I study Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease and PTSD.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Noah Palm
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess I can go. Um, so my name is Noah Palm. I'm an assistant professor of immunobiology um at Yale University. Um, I'm trained kind of as a hardcore immunologist but for the past decade or so I've been working on um both uh immune microbiota interactions as well as now kind of host microbiota interactions more broadly. Um, one of the focuses in my lab has been um development of new technologies to kind of deconvolute the complexity of the microbiome and identify causal and mechanistic roles for specific microbes or microbial products by leveraging new developments in combinatorial biology um uh and next generation sequencing to simultaneously interrogate kind of thousands of possible molecular level interactions between indigenous microbes and their hosts.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dave Durgan
meeting_annotations.transcript: All right, I can go next. Um, my name is Dave Durgan. I'm at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. Uh my background is in cardiovascular physiology. Uh my main interests are in development of hypertension. And so that and I've been looking uh over the last several years at the role of the micro uh biota as well as its metabolites uh and how they regulate host blood pressure. Uh much of this work has been done um in how they affect the vasculature but also how this affects blood pressure regulating nuclei in the brain.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Courtney Robinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, my name is Courtney Robinson. I'm an associate professor of biology at Howard University in Washington DC. And I'm a microbial ecologist. Most of my work is in environmental systems. So I'm interested in um micro interactions in uh insects. And then I'm also interested in things like iodine transformation in soil systems. And the thing that brings me to this group is our work looking at the role of Rexin in uh gut micro uh interactions and at that level.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Erin Longbrake. I'm an assistant professor at Yale. Um I'm a neuroimmunologist, mostly clinical and translational.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: I work in multiple sclerosis.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: And I have an interest in the microbiome.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: As potentially something that might mediate some of the onset of MS.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um either directly or by communications with the immune system.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: And also something that may be manipulated by different immunomodulatory medications that we use for treating our disease states.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: So nice to meet everyone.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sandra Laney
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone. I'm Sandra Laney.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sandra Laney
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh uh director of science innovation at the Walder Foundation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sandra Laney
meeting_annotations.transcript: Really here in in listening and learning mode.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maayan Levy
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'll go next.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maayan Levy
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so I'm Maayan Levy. I'm an assistant professor at Q Penn. Um I started my lab three years ago and we study um generally in the interaction between the host and the microbiome and we're specifically interested in how epithelial cells in the gut are mediating this interaction. Um, we are trying to identify um new metabolites that are being sensed by intestinal epithelial cells and new receptors that are sensing these metabolites.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maayan Levy
meeting_annotations.transcript: Trying to understand what are the consequences of of this detection of metabolites and and how they influence um different intestinal diseases.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maayan Levy
meeting_annotations.transcript: So we work a lot with the mouse models of IBD and colorectal cancer. Um, we work with germ free mice, um as well as in vitro organoid models and and some um cell cultures.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess I'll bring up the rear.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, my name is JP Yu.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm an assistant professor at the University of Wisconsin.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm a physician scientist here.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, clinically uh uh I'm a neuro radiologist here.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: And then my lab uh is really interested in using advanced uh MR and pet technologies.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: To identify neuroimaging biomarkers of neuropsychiatric and neurocognitive illness.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, a lot of that work has been uh designed to try to really unravel the biological transformations that sort of uh are changing the actual parameters that we're measuring on our uh neuroimaging techniques.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: And in our sort of search for these biomarkers.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: We serendipitously started to notice that different gut microbial populations.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um have a a very unexpected and a very large effect on uh neuro microstructure and brain function.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, and as you might imagine that's really going to confound how we measure uh neuroimaging biomarkers.

meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: So now we're very much interested in trying to really uh unravel the relationship between uh and how gut microbiota and these different populations and dysbiosis can lead to different neuroimaging biomarkers in the brain.
